results.title: Animal Logic: Screen Worlds Spotlight interview
results.brief_description: An interview with Animal Logic for Screen Worlds at ACMI. Animal Logic is an animation and visual effects digital studio known for their role on films such as “Happy Feet”, “The Lego Movie” and “Peter Rabbit”.

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: Britain's First Light
results.brief_description:
‘First Light’ is a British wide organisation that uses film and media production to develop skills in young people aged up to 25.
Talented youth from a wide range of backgrounds are provided with training led by film and media industry professionals using industry standard equipment. This collection draws works from several years of this creative partnership.

results.title: Until My Heart's, Like, Finished
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Phil Shepherd, Martin Hodgson, Somerset Film and First Light
results.brief_description: On the day of your 16th birthday, your mum kicks you out of home for good. You live in a car. You sofa surf. You sleep rough. Life for these young people has been tough with many challenges. Here they tell their stories in their own words, reveal they have learnt about how to survive and make plans for putting their lives back together.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Snelling, Phil Shepherd, Martin Hodgson, Somerset Film and First Light

results.title: The Race
results.creator_credit: Nikki Rose, Kinetoscope Productions and First Light
results.brief_description: Neil and David met at nursery school. There was something different about Neil but David liked him, even though he often got himself into a bad temper. Neil knew that because of his condition eventually they would part company but David vowed that they would always remain best friends.

results.title: Prehistoric Pet Shop
results.creator_credit: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light
results.brief_description: Prehistoric Pet Shop is about a caveman whose alarm clock stops working. But not just any alarm clock - the clock was a bird with an unfortunate heart problem. The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. A homage to Monty Python’s parrot sketch, this hilarious short reveals that complaining can get you more than just a new alarm clock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light

The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. results.title: Pirates of the Indian Ocean
results.creator_credit: Omni Rahman, Enamul Khan, Rafi Rahman, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association, Wind & Foster Media and First Light
results.brief_description: Clumsy but lovable DJ duo Mankind and Small-Steps have built a devoted following to their pirate radio show. Raging against the machine in their own inimitable style, will they reach the top of radio programming or be caught on the wrong side of the law before they reach their dream?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Omni Rahman, Enamul Khan, Rafi Rahman, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association, Wind & Foster Media and First Light

results.title: One Week Later
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, PVA Medialab and First Light
results.brief_description: Told through the eyes of a younger pupil, who surveys the relationships his brother has with his peer group. As revelations and misunderstandings occur, due to the misuse of the ubiquitous mobile phone, the week’s events come to a climax on a Friday afternoon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Snelling, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, PVA Medialab and First Light

results.title: One Man's Walk
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Mitchell, Interplay Theatre and First Light
results.brief_description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenneth Mitchell, Interplay Theatre and First Light

results.title: Olympic Legacy: this was forever
results.creator_credit: Mark Aitken, Polkadotsonraindrops and First Light
results.brief_description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.
results.description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.
